Expectation1: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation1: A minor UI glitch occasionally shows up but has an easy workaround
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: Several other volunteers can easily cover the first part of the shift if someone shows up a little late.
Story: I stared at the bug report blinking on my screen, the subject line reading “UI glitch—urgent?” QA had flagged it, but I knew from experience it was minor, and users could refresh the page to fix it. Still, the expectation was clear: as the team’s go-to troubleshooter, I was supposed to jump on these issues, no matter how small. My phone buzzed with a reminder—my volunteer shift started in twenty minutes. I’d promised to be on time, but I also knew the first half hour was always slow, and the other volunteers could easily cover for me if I was late. My manager’s voice echoed in my head, “We need quick turnarounds.” At the same time, I remembered the coordinator’s gentle but firm reminder last week: “Reliability matters.” I felt the pressure mounting, torn between the responsibility to my team and my commitment to the community. My fingers hovered over the keyboard, heart pounding, as I weighed which expectation I would have to let down.
